summary: Charles A. Briggs was involved in handling Freedom of Information and Privacy Acts requests, specifically as the DDO Information Review Officer. He expressed appreciation for the support received from the Privacy and Information Action Group (PIAG) in this role. Later, he appears to have been involved in the CIA's experience with the JFK Records Review, where the agency faced challenges due to deadlines and inflexible standards. The documents suggest he was involved in the process of releasing information related to the JFK assassination, including deliberations with the ARRB regarding redactions and the protection of certain information.
significance: Charles A. Briggs' significance in the JFK context lies in his involvement in the CIA's handling of the release of JFK assassination records and the associated declassification processes. He was involved in navigating the complexities of balancing transparency with the protection of sensitive information during the JFK Records Review.
